work.name: Inocras Inc.
work.position: Computational Genomics Center – Pipeline Development Team
work.summary: In my current role, I focus on `structural variant (SV) calling`, implementing and optimizing SV callers, applying mutation refinements, and enhancing sensitivity in detecting complex genomic alterations. This has led to more accurate variant identification and a reduction in SV calls by up to 78%. I also develop algorithms for actionable findings by integrating, refining, and optimizing data from `The Clinical Knowledgebase (CKB)` into our somatic pipeline to provide precise data for actionable drugs, on-label drug recommendations, and clinical trial matching. Additionally, I contribute to an AI-driven project developing `deep learning-based mutation callers` to enhance mutation detection accuracy and efficiency.
highlights: Genomics
Whole genome sequencing
Mutation detection
Deep learning
Actionable findings

publications.name: Deep learning untangles the resistance mechanism of p53 reactivator in lung cancer cells
publications.summary: Proposed a novel combinatorial target and computational method to overcome drug resistance to p53 activator in lung cancer using GAN and GNN.

projects.name: A Generative Adversarial and Graph Neural Networks Approach to Tackle Drug Resistance
projects.summary: at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST) / Master Thesis & Journal publication & KOR/US patent
highlights: Problem: While the most common TP53 mutations in lung cancer make p53 activator treatments essential, drug resistance significantly limits their effectiveness.

Contributions: Developed a novel computational approach using Generative adversarial networks and Graph neural networks to identify drug resistance mechanisms and therapeutic targets. Conducted in vitro validation, confirming the therapeutic potential of the identified gene targets.
Results: Identified a key pathway and biomarker associated with p53 resistance, leading to a Korean/US patent application and publication in Cell iScience.

projects.name: A systems biological study to investigate the fundamental principle and overcoming method of adaptive resistance to targeted anti-cancer therapy
projects.summary: at Korea Advanced Institute of Science and Technology (KAIST)
highlights: Problem: Overcoming the limitations of colon cancer treatment requires understanding adaptive resistance to targeted therapies, like MEK inhibitors, and developing strategies to combat it.

Contributions: Performed drug concentration and timepoint screenings, established MEK inhibitor-resistant colon cancer cell lines, analyzed gene expression changes in key pathways, and produced RNA sequencing data.
Results: Discovered significant resistance-related genes, supporting model construction and contributing to securing $300K in funding from the National Research Foundation of Korea.

projects.name: Identification of Lifestyle Factors correlated with Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease
projects.summary: at Handong Global University (HGU) / Bachelor Thesis
highlights: Problem: The increasing global incidence of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD) is associated with unhealthy lifestyles, making it crucial to identify contributing lifestyle factors.

Contributions: Collaborated with a physician from Seoul National University Hospital (SNUH) to analyze GERD risk factors using logistic regression, hierarchical clustering, and subgroup analysis on a large patient dataset.
Results: Identified lifestyle factors contributing to GERD risk, which were presented in my bachelor’s thesis.

projects.name: Diabetic Status Monitoring and Prediction using Clinical and Genomic Data
highlights: Problem: Diabetes is a chronic disease that requires continuous monitoring, which can be difficult for patients to manage on their own, highlighting the need for robust predictive tools for prevention and management.
Contributions: Developed a blood glucose level forecasting model using deep neural networks. Analyzed clinical data from SNUH and genomics data from the GWAS catalog.
Results: Built an effective blood glucose prediction model with accurate results, leading to a scholarship award through the Capstone project submission.

projects.name: Bio-synergy: Metabolites Data Analysis
highlights: Problem: Metabolites are crucial for predicting type 2 diabetic status, as diabetes is a metabolic disease; however, accurate predictions depend on effective data preprocessing and appropriate model selection.

Contributions: Preprocessed LC/MS-based metabolite data from the Korea Basic Science Institute using Combat and quantile normalization to reduce non-biological variation. Improved a diabetes prediction model by applying elastic net regression.
Results: Enhanced prediction accuracy and gained experience in handling metabolite data.
